titleStmt.title: Description of Columbia University MS Or 458: Dalāʼil al-khayrāt wa-shawāriq al-anwār fī dhikr al-ṣalāh ʻalá al-Nabī al-mukhtār.

msContents.summary: Illustrated copy of the popular prayer book.

msItem.title: Dalāʼil al-khayrāt wa-shawāriq al-anwār fī dhikr al-ṣalāh ʻalá al-Nabī al-mukhtār.
دلائل الخيرات وشوارق الانوار في ذكر الصلاة على النبي المختار
Dalāʼil al-khayrāt washawāriq al-anwār fī dhikr al-ṣalāh ʻalá al-Nabī al-mukhtār

supportDesc.extent: i, 103, i leaves : 176 x 113 (103 x 60) mm, bound to 165 x 115 x 20 mm

layoutDesc.layout: 11 long lines; border-ruled; catchwords every verso, lower left; some leaves have a grid pattern (f. 11r-16v).

scriptDesc.scriptNote: Written in naskh in black ink; pointed, vocalized.

decoDesc.decoNote: Polychrome and gold illuminated headpieces (f. 1v, 20v), will gold, foliate marginal fill on the page-opening and the text on cloudbands (f. 1v-2r, 20v-21r); double-page illustration of Mecca and Medina in perspective (f. 18v-19r); numerous polychrome and gold text dividers; marginal medallions in polychrome and gold; gold roundels with red and blue dots puncuate the text; textblock border-ruled in double gold, black and red with page-opening frame-ruled in blue; finispiece in bright blue with floral design (f. 98r); colophon surround of polychrome flowers on a gold field (f. 101r).

binding.p: Dark reddish-brown leather with envelope flap, gold stamped in a two-register design of a central mandorla with two pendants on the vertical axis and cornerpieces surrounded by a frame itself surrounded by a set of gold cartouches and another, outside frame; matching pendant, cornerpieces and frame on the flap; marbled paper doublure and endleaves.

origin.p: Copy completed on 15 Dhū al-Qaʻdah 1251 AH by Ḥasan al-Shawqī, a student of his father and teacher Khalīl al-Shākir Afandī, the muezzin for the Mosque of Arslan Pasha, which is built into the citadel of the town of Yānīyah (Ioannina, Greece) (f. 101r).

history.provenance: Gift of Morris H. Saffron (library bookplate inside front cover).
